After struggling to change clothing while lying down (I could barely kneel, let alone stand), and suffering through a fairly sleepless/stuffy night in the Eureka tent, I decided that the following features were necessary for comfortable camping: 1. The ability to stand up fully. This meant that any tent I chose had to have a center height of at least 72", preferably more (my husband is 6 feet tall, and if I ever want him to join us camping, the tent needs to work for him too. The Montana 8 has a center height of 84" (7 feet). 2. Room for gear and at least two full/queen sized air mattresses. Although the Montana 8 states that there's room for 8 people, the diagram shows these 8 people sleeping in mummy bags very close together. From a comfort perspective, this tent will hold 4-5 people (and their gear) at a maximum, without feeling overly crowded. For the three of us, this fits the bill nicely. 3. Intuitive and easy to set up and take down. While I like camping, I am not an avid camper. Finding a tent that can be set up (and taken down) with only help from a 9 year old was key, and this fits the bill nicely. 4. Good cross-ventilation. After sleeping in a stuffy tent once, I didn't want to repeat the experience. Three windows (the two side windows and the door window) can be rolled down to allow for good air flow and ventilation. We rolled the windows down 1/3 of the way, which provided a very comfortable cross-breeze while sleeping. 5. Waterproof with a bathtub floor. Many of the reviewers stated that they had no problems with leaks along the seams without using any waterproofing sealant. After talking with others and reading some recommendations, I used the Kiwi Camp Dry Heavy Duty Water Repellent to spray the seams prior to our first use, as added protection. We had some light rain during the evening, and much heavier rain the next morning, and the inside of the tent stayed bone dry. 6. Quality. I wanted a tent that would stand up to occasional car camping trips, without having to be replaced on a regular basis. Coleman is a recognized brand, and after talking with folks who own Coleman tents and reading the reviews, I was convinced that this tent would be a good one for our family. So far, I'm pleased! 6. Price. Given that we don't do a lot of camping, I didn't want to spend hundreds on a tent. I purchased the Montana 8 in Blue (not the Elite) from Amazon in mid-May 2015, and paid $136.48; a surprisingly low price for this particular tent model/size. Some nice features that this tent offers (that weren't on my list of must-haves): 1. A port for electrical/extension cords. While this tent does not have electricity, it does include a port near the door that allows campers to run an extension cord into the tent (for use with lanterns, fans, etc.) 2. A covered entry area. I looked at tents that had screened in areas, but opted for this one instead, choosing to have the extra room inside the tent rather than in a screened area. I had two camp chairs outside - in the evening, when it started to rain, I placed the camp chairs under the front rain fly "awning", on either side of the door. Despite the rain, the chairs stayed mostly dry, with only a few drops of water on them. 3. A "D door". This door has a pole that threads around the D curve, and another one at the hinge axis, which means that the door can function as a real door in terms of opening/closing, rather than a door that must be zipped open and closed. While there are Velcro closures around the D curve, we found that to keep insects from getting in we still had to zip it shut. However, we liked the easy entry! All in all, my family and I are very pleased with our new tent, and look forward to many years of use!

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
review_header: Reviewed tents for weeks before settling on this one.
review_text: Let me see if I can be thorough about this. Our family needed a tent. Our other one was a hand-me-down two personer. We have 2 kids now so it just wasn't cutting it. I am not a camping lover, so I am not looking for a tent that can withstand the elements, so I cannot state how it holds up to rain. But it was CRAZY windy when we used it and the tent did fine. As for the easiness to set up, this tent was a dream. I don't camp, but still was able to put up this tent by myself, with a toddler helping me. The tent only has a few poles to push through. The hardest set up part was actually the frame for the door with was VERY tight so needed to be zipped up before putting the ends where they needed to be. The framed front door made it easier for my toddler to hold open and get in. The size of the tent is dreamy. We have a queen air mattress, a giant dog bed, a baby rock n' play and a toddler mattress and still have room for my son to run from bed to bed. With all the screens, it made withstanding the wind no problem. It just rolled right through. Putting the tent away was a little bit harder. Just trying to figure out how to package everything back up. I think we had the tent put back just fine, but I don't think we got the rain fly back in the bag. It is also huge, so you need LOTS of space to fold it up nicely. We love it so far!

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
reviewed_product_attribute: Style: Tent | Size: 16 x 7 | Color: Green
review_header: Exactly What Coleman Says... I love this tent!
review_text: I am tall and this tent is perfect. It is everything Coleman said it is: waterproof, weatherproof, roomy, easy to assemble and disassemble and lots of storage spaces. All the parts were included and me and my brother in law set this up right out of the box in less than 30 minutes. Great ventilation and privacy. It really keeps the bugs out and the way the floor is molded to the sides is ingenious. I can't believe how nice this tent is. If you are looking at this tent, you will not find it cheaper than Amazon. I really got my money's worth and can't wait to go camping again. Good for summer months, since you can't put a portable heater in it. I would not use this tent for cold nights. One night, the outdoor temperature went down to 49 F. That's about as cold as I can stand, without a portable heater. Other than that caveat, this tent is a winner. I love it.

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
review_header: Lots of space, easy set up and teardown, and other features
review_text: Just tested this tent out a few weeks ago. First time setting up a tent in my life, got it set up in about 20 minutes by myself using instructions. Plenty of space could easily have space to fit a queen sized double high air mattress on both sizes of the tent and still have plenty of space in the middle to stores your belongings. This was a great tent, easy set up, easy teardown. I like the windows layout allows for a good cross breeze when you want. also has pockets and hooks throughout the inside of the tent. Loved this tent, can’t wait to use it again.

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
reviewed_product_attribute: Style: Tent | Size: 16 x 7 | Color: Green
review_header: Stayed Dry Through Heavy Rain Storms.
review_text: The first time I unpacked this tent for use a heavy thunderstorm rolled in. It rained on us off and on for 24 hours. About 10 mph winds. Pretty heavy rainfall led to pools of water all around the OUTSIDE of the tent. Being an avid camper I know that on any polyester tent when it’s raining it doesn’t matter what kind of water proofing the manufacturer boasts that it’s best not to actually touch the tent. Touching the tent with water on the other side enables the water to bleed through much like a glass of ice water does when it creates condensation. I instructed my three kids not to touch the tent any more than they had to while it was pouring rain. We stayed bone dry! We had plenty of room for two small cots, a crib, and air mattress, and games in the center floor. At the price point I’m extremely satisfied with my purchase. (For those in the reviews who did not stay dry I wonder if they know that installing the rain fly correctly is required for effectiveness).

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
review_text: I purchased this tent the other day and decided to do a trial setup before camping. The tent is great!!! The setup directions are not so great. It maybe obvious to most people, but keep this in mind during setup… (1) The two longest poles (black) crisscross over the center of the tent and slides into the small silver post located at the stake loops. Set these first. (2) The next two longest poles (gray) go on both ends where the windows are and slides into the same small silver post located at the stake loops. We ran these poles after we set the first poles, but you maybe able to run these with the first set of poles and simply let them dangle while you set the first poles. (3) The last pole (black with red tip ends) are for the rainfly and is “sleeved” through the FRONT side rainfly and…on the door side and slides into the small sliver post located at the stake loops. The Coleman logo should be on the door side of the tent. (4) The two last small black poles are for the door, and it is pretty self-explanatory. (5) Observe closely how the tent was packaged during the initial unpacking so you will know how to fold it so the tent fits back in the carry bag. It took my wife and me about 20 minutes on the initial setup, but it shouldn’t take any more that 10-15 after the trial run. I hope this helps.

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
review_text: This is the first family tent that I've bought other than a backyard pop-up. Size: it fits four people well with air mattresses at either end. I can see fitting 6 people in a row lengthwise, but it's hard to see how 8 people could fit unless no one used air mattresses and you were side by side like sardines. Interior space: The center has a good amount of head space, if you put the sleeping bags at either end, it makes a comfortable space. There is a side pocket on either end to store things and a light hook at each end and in the center. The zip opening for an electric cord is handing, although it would be nice to have one on the other side as you either have to orient the tent towards the outlet or have a long extension cord. I really like the structure to the door. Set up and take down: it's easy to put up once you know where everything goes. There were a couple of steps on the instructions that were a little confusing, basically everything connects to the silver rings. Once you understand that, it's easy. The take down only takes about 5 minutes. The hard part is folding it to get back in the case. The first time we used it, I was able to get the tent back into the case, but there is no way the rain fly was going back in. The second time, I couldn't even get the tent in and zipped. There must be a trick to getting all the air out and it flat enough, but I haven't figured it out yet. Weathering the elements: We've used this twice. The first time, it stood up under very windy conditions. The tents of people around us were collapsing, but this little tent held up to the winds. We haven't used it in rain yet. Edited May 2018: We took this out on a trip in some Houston rains and I didn't notice any leaking at all. Packing up, I asked another camper the trick to getting a tent rolled up tight enough to get it back in the case. The trick is the tent poles. Lay down your tent pole bag at the end of the tent and fold the tent in thirds so that the folded tent is no wider than the tent pole bag. Then place your pole bag at the end of the tent and begin to slowly roll up the tent, allowing the weight of the poles to push the air out of the tent. The experienced camper told me it was important to go slow and not force the air out or it could damage the tent. Since the tent is a rectangular dome, there will be more tent in the center, so you have to be sure to keep folding in the extra as you roll up to it. The trick is when you come to the other end. Since it has a tub bottom, all the air will be pushed ballooning up that waterproof (and airproof) area. There will be no place for the air to escape. To get the last bit of air out, roll back the end you've been rolling over the stakes until you come to the end wall window. Next roll up the end you've been trying to reach, which is ballooned up. So the pole end is just unrolled to the window and the opposite end is rolling TO the window, pushing out all the trapped air. Unroll the end with the poles to the opposite end again. If there is still too much air, repeat until the whole thing will roll flat. I had to do this three times, but in the end everything fit. I was able to fit everything back into the case completely with room to spare.

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
reviewed_product_attribute: Style: Lighted Tent | Size: 8-Person | Color: Blue
review_text: We bought this tent for our first camping trip with our 7-month-old baby, and have now used it a few times. I didn't think I'd like the hinged door but it turns out to be very useful to pop in and out of the tent w/o having to zip, and the built in lights seemed unnecessary but are actually great -- the dim orange level is perfect for sneaking into the tent after the baby is asleep! It's more difficult to set up than the little 3-person tent we had before, but with the 2 of us doing it we didn't take much longer than our friends setting up their smaller tent. It seemed embarrassingly big the first time we set it up, but is actually a perfect size for a family of 3 or 4. With a queen blow up mattress + pack n play we had plenty of room for all of our stuff and walking around! Would absolutely recommend especially for the price!

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
reviewed_product_attribute: Style: Lighted Tent | Size: 8-Person | Color: Blue
review_text: This tent is awesome. Set-up was quick and easy. Family of four fit no problem during our week long camping trip. The LED light was a nice touch. There was some heavy rain one night... Inside was dry. Not the best picture, but helps show the size against the RAM 1500.

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
review_text: This thing is a beast! I love it! I (a 29 y/o female) got it up by myself in about 30 minutes- I'm sure someone who puts up tents more frequently could get it up faster though! Went together easily and gave us plenty of room! We had 2 twin air mattresses, 2 folding chairs, a camping table and 2 large dogs with plenty of room to spare! Great purchase! Can't wait to take it out again! Please ignore the messy campsite!

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
reviewed_product_attribute: Style: Tent | Size: 16 x 7 | Color: Green
review_text: We are not avid campers and go about once a year. I was looking for a large tent for four people that could handle a queen blow up bed. This one was the right price and size and reviews seemed to be positive. The setup was a bit difficult to do in pitch black with flashlights but we were able to set it all up in around 30 min. It is a very light weight tent and I am not sure how weatherproof it would be but my guess is not great. I would not even attempt to camp with this in a rain storm. We went camping in an area that got a lot of smoke from the fires in CA last year and inside the tent was more like a BBQ with the smoke. If you are looking for a large size tent it will hold two queen air mattresses but not give you a lot of other space. Comfortably this is a four person tent with all the typical camping gear, lights, bags etc...

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
reviewed_product_attribute: Style: Lighted Tent | Size: 8-Person | Color: Blue
review_text: I don't know whether to praise Amazon or Coleman but I love them both! We are getting back to tent camping after 15 years camping in a travel trailer. First on the agenda...buy a tent, of course. So we went to a local sporting goods store and bought a moderately priced tent. Brought it home and tried to set it up only to find the elastic in one of the tent poles was in shreds. Packed it up, returned it. Bought the next step up tent and parts were missing. Went to Walmart and bought one from them...the catch to extend the pole on one of the poles was broken and placed upside down. We have reservations at a camp on the 11th so time is running short. Plus, here in Sacramento California we are having 100'F temps so setting up and taking down tents is not fun. Finally, I said Amazon to the rescue. We purchased this Coleman Elite Montana 8-person tent. It arrived as promised on Sunday, July 9 as promised. And it went up easily and is without a flaw anywhere. Great design, handy features and decent quality craftsmanship. I'm 69 and have used Coleman products my whole life and never had cause to doubt them. Don't bother with those other brands. Get Coleman, save yourself grief.

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
review_header: Room for the whole family (and the dog).
review_text: Great tent with a LOT of room inside. We put 2 queen blowup mattresses in it and had a ton of extra space (I think we could have fit a third queen mattress in between them). Only took about 30 mins to setup the first time. The only negative is the poles aren’t labeled, nor color coded, so there’s a bit of guess and check to find the right poles (but fairly easy if you are familiar with setting up a tent).

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
reviewed_product_attribute: Style: Lighted Tent | Size: 8-Person | Color: Blue
review_text: I have used this tent on two occasions so far and have found it to be very spacious and seemingly sturdy. The LED light and switch is also very nice and a convenience I would choose the elite over the regular to have, as are the quick roll windows. So far we have camped in good weather so I can't attest to the tents handling of wind or rain. I have only a few very minor complaints or observations about the tent. First, setting up the tent itself is fairly simple and quick; both times I even managed to do it myself with no assistance though a second person would be helpful. The rainfly however is a tad tedious; it is hard to get on the tent as it is so tall, I'd almost recommend putting it over the tent before raising it. The fly also has about a thousand Velcro straps to tie it down with. Once I located them all the second time I put it up I was much faster but it's still a chore. I would skip the fly if you know the weather will be good. As others have noted the Velcro holding the door shut doesn't always fit well; we mostly use the zipper unless coming back through the door almost immediately. Our other tents all had zippered doors so this isn't a huge deal. It would also be nice if the door had a catch so it would stay open if you wanted to. I also found it inconvenient that there isn't any sort of hook at the top of the tent to hold a fan; my other Coleman tent has a clip to hang a tent fan and the Montana elite just had the light there. Again, a very minor thing but if you camp in hot weather a lot it might be an issue. Over all we are very happy with the Montana elite 8. It has more than enough room without being too bulky or unmanageable. It's straightforward to assemble and seems built to last. I would recommend it to anyone looking to move to a bigger tent that could easily sleep 6 with everyone on there own air mattress with room to spare for gear.

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
reviewed_product_attribute: Style: Tent | Size: 16 x 7 | Color: Green
review_text: My family and I generally go camping 5-6 times each summer. This year we needed to replace our previous tent and decided to go with a Coleman tent because of the ease of ordering replacement parts if need be. Originally bought the "Coleman Red Canyon 8 Person Tent" and one of the poles broke on the first set-up. Decided to try this tent because we liked the idea of a door. The tent goes up easily if you have ever put a tent up before. The poles seem very sturdy and the tent is spacious enough for 2 full size & 1 twin air mattresses with very little walking space. In my mind, tents are made to sleep in or get out of the rain if need be. This tent has very adequate airflow even with the rain fly on, literally no condensation on the walls through the night. Without the rain fly you have a great view of the sky. The hinged door is a truly nice feature. It is held in place by several large pieces of Velcro attached to the tent and door when you close it and works very well for small children (5, 7, & 8) to get in and out of the tent without help. We camped at Mammoth Cave National Park for 7 nights recently and honestly could not have been more pleased with a tent. It was very hot and muggy during the trip but the air circulation in the tent was nice. We only had one small thunderstorm during the trip and the tent showed no signs o leaking. I WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS TENT!!!!

product_title: Coleman 8-Person Tent for Camping | Elite Montana Tent with Easy Setup
review_text: We needed to upgrade from our previous tent and go this one. It's a big tent! We are a family of 5 and a dog. We used 4 Cots and a pack n play so we could stash our gear under them, but I wouldn't put more than 5 people in this tent with any more gear. It's really nice to be able to stand up straight in the tent and the hinged door is a great bonus. Only negative thing I currently have about the door is that it is a big step to get over the side of the tent to get in. So if you have little kids or mobility issues, it will be a struggle until the kids get bigger. But it wasn't really that big of a deal for us. I have set this up 3 times. Once with another person and Twice on my own. Easily doable on your own. Doesn't take that much more time either. I looked at the elite version for a long time before purchasing this tent. I didn't think the extras were worth the cost. We purchased our own lamp that we hung in the middle of the tent on the hook and it worked just fine. And the windows are so small, the self rolling feature wouldn't have made much of a difference. We camped when it was dry so I have nothing to add about waterproofing except I bought some water guard and seam sealer. Will update in the future if we camp during the rainy season.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I picked up a Ruger Mark IV Lite 22/45 and was looking for an inexpensive optic to add to it. As it's a plinking .22, I wasn't looking for an extremely durable sight that would be lots of abuse. I saw the reviews on this and decided to give it a shot. I couldn't be happier. I had it sighted in over 20 rounds and am very happy with its consistency at 50ft. Have since put over 1000 rounds through and the accuracy hasn't changed. Battery life is pretty good. Accidentally left the sight on (3) for 5 days while it was resting in its case. Discovered it when I went to the range and it was still bright and ready to go. The photos include: Installed photo on the Mark IV 10-rounds @ 50ft 20-rounds @ 50ft 200-rounds @ 50ft

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: New version with silver letters (not white or gold) seems fine
review_text: So many reviewers don't realize the front lens is supposed to be slanted; and guess what, me too, but google is kind and proved that is normal. Looks like I got a new version with the silver letters that don't have the little r logo. I was alarmed to say the least given all the negative reviews about fake products. But having checked Bushnell's site, they have this version on there so not gonna worry much more. Everything checks out for me, and to be honest didn't at first. Definitely they are cutting costs in various ways to keep this price point, but comparing this to a 2013 (gold letter) model I got new (and just returned), it looks like my silver letter modern version is better quality than that, with some minor not so important differences in details. I don't care if it has an etched dot vs a printed one for the setting indicator. I'm not worried if it doesn't have the two holes on the front lens cap Doesn't bother me that the battery cap is slightly shallower on the threads. My lenses are clean; nothing, but what's supposed to be in the inside is there, and the windage and elevation turrets are solid while being easy to use (don't care that it don't say something on the underside of the cover caps- clearly shows an R with an arrow and up with an arrow on the knobs). The setting dial is firm yet smooth to turn. I like how they have the circled B logo behind the setting indicator dot. So far, thing shoots accurately as far as this amateur can tell; will see how durable it is and update. One person mentioned that the older versions were brighter and I found that to be the opposite, which is also worth mentioning: on settings 9-11 (at least for me) it's too bright and has a glare that is annoying, but with shades on I found even setting 3, in really bright sunlight, is plenty bright enough with a crisp dot. I feel lucky because of all the negative comments, mine works well and hopefully will continue to. End of the day, solid budget entry level Red Dot Optic. Edit 3/20: Went to the range today and have learned things. 1.) Do not mount this partially on your handrail, keep it on the receiver 2.) Use blue thread locker to make sure everything is nice and tight/won't loosen after some use. 3.) Removing the sticker on the battery cap is a pain in the butt 4.) After 190 rounds through my firearm with this scope (and once I used blue thread locker), this thing is zeroed and stays zeroed. My buddy, a first time shooter, shot a 1 inch group @ 50 yds with 4 solid center bullseye hits. Needless to say he's a champ! And so is this budget optic. Keeping mines, hope yours turns out great too.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: Stock photos make it difficult to see just how small and compact the TRS-25 is. I was beyond satisfied with a Bushnell Trophy 28 purchase, but I wanted a low profile red dot for a 10/22 build. I did not want to add a cheek riser to compensate for a high red dot mount. I considered several open red dots, but for under $50 and all the positive reviews, I mounted this TRS-25 to my rifle. It is small and compact - you can almost close your fingers around the entire unit. Briefly, I feared it was too small, but once on, I realized how quickly I could site with a flat M-4 style stock. Unbelievably, the dot was right on target after mounting. I haven't done any precise shooting, but the first few hundred rounds were accurate and target acquisition was quick. The 11 levels of brightness are a little overkill for me (4-5 would suffice), but the dot is easy to see and very crisp. I would purchase this item again for other weapons.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: Mounted on an AR10. Used a .83 riser and it co-witnessed perfectly with the iron sights. It’s made “over there”, but you can tell it’s well built, especially at this price. Never had a problem with Bushnell products. I bought a Cmore tac rail red dot, figuring it would win the contest and I’d send this one back. Nope. The Bushnell had a wider field and felt solid. Easy adjustments that click when you un screw the caps. Light and small. I did get the newer one with white lettering, but never owned the old gold lettered edition. This seems fine to me.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I was a little hesitant to purchase this after reading some of the reviews. I also didn’t know if it would be too large for the application I wished to use it for (pistol, not rifle). I’m pleased to say it worked out very well. The “wash out” in sunlight others have reported is not a factor for me. I can clearly see the dot, even on some of the lower intensity settings, in direct sunlight. In addition, the optic is small enough to mount to the rail on my pistol and not add a bunch of weight. Sure, you could get a smaller Vortex or Trijicon sight (for 3-4x the price), but that is overkill IMO for a .22. This is a nice little quality red dot that doesn’t break the bank.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: A long way from my 4x scope in the 70's....
review_text: Obviously gun tech has advanced since I got a 4x scope on my Marlin Glenfield 22 in the late 70's, but this little optic is amazing. One of the first things I bought after getting back into target shooting was a cheap scope(I'm more about the Iron Sights), and it was pretty amazing and it was familiar tech to me. Bought this Bushnell just to see what all the red-dot hype was about. After sighting it in with far too many rounds (learning curve) this thing is absolutely spot-on accurate. Being stuck at an indoor range, 40 yards out was a tight group and lots of key holes. Looking forward to 200+ yards at the outdoor range. There is a bit of a downside though, the accuracy is so tight with a red-dot it does take some of the fun out of target shooting. With iron sights there's more of a challenge to shooting, each shot has a little uncertainty to it- more of a skill challenge. A red-dot at 40 yards is kind of like hitting a hole-in-one every swing on the golf course. Reward vs challenge just isn't the same. Though I won't be taking it off my AR any time soon. It is a great optic.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Best bang for your buck for red-dot
review_text: I don't think you'll find something much better for the price. I bought this for my Ruger Charger, and it works quite well. My 5 year old daughter is able to consistently hit a 10 inch target at 25 yards. The dot is less bright than my Trijicon MRO, but they are otherwise quite similar. I actually like the blued-type finish on the Bushnell better than the easily-gouged rubbery finish on the Trijicon. The Trijicon appears to be more solid in construction, and I'd be much more comfortable relying on it in an emergency than the Bushnell. However, for a plinker, this is perfect. The red dot is about as crisp as the Trijicon. BTW, this comes with a battery already installed, but some genius at the Bushnell factory in China puts a clear (nearly invisible) plastic disc underneath the battery so that it won't drain the battery before purchase. You'll need to take this thing out.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Great red dot, great quality, and even better price.
review_text: I am glad that I purchased this, it has been a good little red dot for me so far. I got this for my M&P 15-22 as the price was good and I've had good luck with Bushnell in the past. I didn't want to spend a huge amount of money on a red dot for the 15-22, but I wanted something that would work and last. My friend got a cheap $30 knock off and you can really tell the difference. His brightness nob has very weak detents, so it rotates very loosely compared to the Bushnell. I had ordered the TRS-25 and received it a couple days before picking up my 15-22, so it was ready when I went to the range right after picking up the gun. The red dot only took a couple small adjustments the first time using it, so I was impressed that even after shipping it was pretty close to being on point straight out of the box. After finishing at the range, I realized that the red dot would not fit in the box with the gun to take it home, so I took it off and later put it back on when I got home. A couple weeks later I went to the range again and was surprised that it was still pretty close to being on point. I highly recommend this to people that want a simple red dot that is not going to break the bank. I paid about $70 for this and that is considerably cheaper than what the local gun shops were selling them for. I also had a different friend that was thinking about getting a TRS-25 and after shooting my 15-22 and checking out the TRS-25, he will be getting one soon.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: At the time I ordered this I was unaware of the apparent issues of the white vs gold label. While waiting I did more internet research and was possibly anticipating buyer's remorse as the gold label seemed to be much more desirable. I understand that the gold is the 1st gen model and was held in high regard while many were not impressed with the white. I received the white as I expected. For what it's worth all the problems I read about w/ the white label must've been resolved because I like what I got. The brightness is intense and quite visible even on white paper. The dot doesn't vanish no matter what extreme angle it's being looked through. The knob has nice crisp turns that feel very positive and not mushy like some I've read about. I'm back to not caring about what stupid color the letters are. This red dot is for my Rossi R92 in 357 mag. The stock sights on that thing shoot unusually high @ ~50 yards and this seemed like a good alternative. A 21st century optic on a late 19th century design may look a bit off kilter but this is just what my rifle needed. Buy it!

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I had been looking for a red dot sight to replace the iron sights on my Hi-Point 9mm Carbine Rifle. The iron sights were quite accurate, but I wanted a red dot since they are a little easier on the eyes. After reading lots of reviews, I found that most sights with great reviews were several hundreds of dollars. This was the best reviewed sight I could find for under $100. I was very impressed with the quality. It's more compact than I thought it would be, and sits low to the rail so I needed a 1/2" riser to use it comfortably (not a problem if your rifle has a raised rail). It uses small watch-style batteries so I ordered some extras to have on hand (since I took off the iron sights). The 11 brightness settings should cover all your needs; I use 1 for an indoor range that's pretty dimly lit and 11 is extremely bright, even enough so for a sunny day. The first time I took the sight out to the range (25 yard indoor range) I had forgotten the manual and I've never sighted in a red dot or scope before. It was only a few inches off when I first installed it, and I was able to sight it in within about 30 minutes. Pros: *Slightly better accuracy than the iron sights, but much faster target acquisition time. *Easy on the eyes and you can shoot with both eyes open and still see the target clearly down range with the dot on it. *Bright crisp dot. As I read in other reviews, don't make it too bright or it will look blurry. May not look right in fluorescent lighting. *Feels solid. It's really compact but also heavy for it's size (better than being made of plastic). *Has a really cool looking yellow/gold tint on the outside of the "business end" of the lens. Slight blue tint from viewing end. *Everyone who has tried shooting my carbine with it loves it. Keep in mind that this isn't a scope so there is no magnification. The benefit is that you can use both eyes to aim, but this isn't going to help you get extremely precise accuracy at range. Personally I've been looking at magnifiers to install in conjunction with this sight. This will definitely be my "go to" sight for any future purchases.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: If you're anything like me, you only write reviews when something is either really not worth purchasing, or that you love a product so much, you gotta let everyone and their mothers know about it.... And I really want your mommy knowing about this product! Short version: Stop thinking about it and buy it... Or have mommy buy it for you! Long Version: So I ordered on a Thursday, and thank you Prime and my local UPS guy for having it delivered to me by Saturday because I reserved a spot at my local outdoor range for Sunday morning with the intentions of putting my AR-15 through it's paces. Installed it Saturday night and sighted it in by only lollipop'in it with by flip up sights. I have a laser bore sight but I didn't want to point my AR at my neighbors house who's back porch is exactly 25 yards away in the middle of the night and have my local PD knocking on my door. Soooooo.... After sighting it in my garage like that, I waited for the range the next morning. I was biting my nails as to how accurate it was going to be at 25 yards, and wouldn't you know it... Bullseye! Set up metal targets at 50 yards, 75 yards and 100... Guess what.. 'plink plink plink!!' paired it up with a beat up UTG 3x magnifier that I've been using for years... perfect combo for me!! Just make sure you have an 1" riser for the red dot... Can't believe I waited 3 years after purchasing my AR to buy this small, yet robust piece of gold!! Go tell your mom!!

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: Bushnell did an amazing job with this Red Dot. It's simple & affordable to me! I was able to pull it out of the box and get it mounted on my AR easily. I'm not one to read instructions.. LOL , I just don't like to. So I pulled it out of the box. Took the dust covers off the lenses. Most important detail to do before mounting it onto your firearm , is to unscrew the little batter cap cover. The power/light switch has a small screw-able cap. Remove that cap then gently without destroying one of the batter holding prongs take out the battery (battery is a flat style battery you would find in a watch). Once you remove the battery, you'll see a small clear circular cover. Take that out of the batter housing area then replace the battery back into the position it was originally. Screw the battery cap cover back on and you're good to GO! Red dot comes with an Allen Wrench tool that is easy to use for the mounting of your new Red Dot. The base unloosens and tightens with that tool. I was able to do all this in about 5-10 minutes give or take. Looks great on my 458 Rifle. The lighting levels of the Red dot can be enhanced considerably and allows you to get a good sight on target even in low light conditions. Army Veteran approved!!

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: The cheapest optic I'd bet my life on
review_text: And I do mean cheapest. You can find better optics, but you'll spend more, and you can find cheaper optics, but you will sacrifice reliability. I think this represents the bare minimum amount of money you can spend on an optic that will take a lickin' and keep on tickin' as the saying goes. I haven't tortured mine (it lives on my 10/22), but I know people who have, on ARs, AKs, and PCCs, and they swear by it.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: Added this sight to my Ruger PC9 carbine 9mm rifle. I did not have to adjust anything. I put it on, went to the range to sight it in, and it was dead on... No adjustment needed. This is an amazing sight, it allows me to accurately hit a Target rapidly, allows the use of the current iron sights too! Looking through the sight,I can use my iron sights without taking off the red Dot sight. I'd ordered 45°offset flip up sights for use in case is needed fixed sights because of dead batteries, but I don't need them. I can shoot better and faster than I've ever shot before. I can even hit swinging targets, which I never could before, and can shoot with both eyes open. You won't regret adding this baby in your gun. Highly recommend.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Best in the price range probably
review_text: It's a TRS-25. Works great. Red dot looks bad at full brightness in a dark room. So turn it down or aim at a brighter area. That's the first thing I hated, and then figured out I was doing in wrong. Somehow I keep hitting the brightness dial and turning it on, and finding out a few days later when the battery is dead. Maybe it's just me, but be mindful of that. Sighting out of the box, it was way off, but it was on a riser, and that's why you sight these things in the first place. Easy to get on target quickly, and even with 3 MOA dot, 100 yard shots are easy peasy. Haven't had any issues staying on zero with moderate to high recoil.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: Great red dot for the price. I put it on my Ruger 22/45 Lite pistol with no problems. Zero'd it in at 25 yards and ran 500 rounds through it without a single problem Zero stayed right where it should be and the mount was rock solid. I got the white lettering version and my LED is at the 4:30 position. The red dot is visible through all of the glass and is the same intensity no matter where I look through it. The dial is a bit stiff but with use it should loosen up. I'll probably get another one for an SBR I'm building.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I bought this sight to co-witness with my Tech-Sights TRS200R on my Ruger 10/22 because it was one of the red dots listed that would work for this purpose. I was pleasantly surprised by the level of quality at this price point. The only other red dots I have owned are Aimpoints, but I am not putting one on a 22 :-) . While not equivalent to the nearly $500 optic, the TRS-25 is really a good optic and the dot is very visible without distortion. The clicks when adjusting were positive. While I love my Aimpoint this is really a usable sight. I'd like to try it on a larger caliber rifle to see how well it holds zero. It has held zero perfectly with 22lr. I don't think it would accept the same level of beating an Aimpoint would, but that's why people pay a lot for that. I do think it seems well sealed and would take some knocks. I'm considering buying another one.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I believe that the red dot unit I received is used. The directions state: "Remove the battery cap an install the battery". When I received the unit, I removed the battery cap and the battery was already installed. It has circular scratch marks on it made by the spring when someone installed it. I removed the battery and tested it. The battery is dead. At this point, I don't even know if the unit functions. I will have to purchase a new battery and see if the unit even works. I am very skeptical, because if it works, why would someone return it. Update... I bought new batteries and the unit DOES NOT WORK. FURTHER UPDATE: Amazon made everything right. They sent me a new Bushnell red dot the very next day. They also made returning the defective red dot very simple for me.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I wanted a small, simple. lightweight sight for a particular application and this one fits the bill. The mount stays tight and the dot stays zero after about 200 rounds of 7.62X39 rifle cartridges. I didn't initially give it 5 stars for two reasons. I can't see the brightest setting against sunlit snow or sand unless I wear sunglasses. Not a deal breaker. The click settings are stiff and not as positive as I'd like. I have to visually check to make sure the dot is on (or off when I put it to sleep). maybe it will improve with use. Also not a deal breaker just a little inconvenient. It seems a robust and reliable sight and I have no reservations recommending it to others. By the way, the lens caps are a little awkward. If you read the instructions you'll find they are meant to be pulled off to the side and left on the sight. If you follow the instructions they are less clumsy and less likely to get lost. Update: After torture testing I've upgraded to 5 stars. This sight is Lock Tited to a rail which is screwed and JB Welded to the gas tube of an SKS rifle. A VERY challenging mounting option. Cold the gas tube has some wiggle, hot the gas tube has considerable wiggle and by hot I mean blister your fingers hot after 50 rounds. At 150 yds I could ring 12" x 20" steel silhouettes about 8 out of 10 shots and at 100yds a 22 round group on paper averaged 4.4" diameter centered 0.25" from the X. Extreme Spread was 6.4". Considering it's a 4 MOA dot, 3 MOA Wolf steel ammo through a well used 60 year old rifle I think this sight is extraordinary for about $65. I'm also pretty astonished that the wiggly gas tube mount returns to zero in the few seconds between shots. P.S. Battery life could be better but riding a hot rail might have something to do with it.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Excellent optic at a good price
review_text: Just got this, so I can't tell you how well it will last, but from what I've seen so far, it's well-made and sturdy. I always have reservations about Chinese-made items, but at this price I thought I'd give it a go. The red dot itself is well-defined, with no noticeable distortion. It comes with nice little rubber lens covers, which I'm sure I will lose within a week. Also comes with a cleaning cloth, which is a nice touch. I have mounted this one to my Ruger 10/22 Takedown, for two reasons: 1. Recoil will never be an issue and I can safely say I don't expect any shock-based failures, and 2. I can't mount a scope as the rifle will no longer fit into the bag Ruger issues with the rifle. Red dot is the fallback, and a good one, since my eyes are old and it's doubtful I'll be shooting that rifle past 20 yards. If I want to shoot a 22LR farther, I'll just use my scoped Savage bolt action. Fit and finish are good. The intensity knob also houses the battery compartment, which takes an inexpensive and readily obtainable CR 2032 disc-type battery. Had it at the range today. easy to zero. Fun to use. I'll report back if my situation changes, but for now, this is a five-for-five optic

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I looked back thru my purchase history as I couldn’t remember when I bought. Reason being I only paid 56.00 for mine. Same link. Now I see it’s what 79.00? I don’t understand the pricing but I do know both is way cheaper than what these go for elsewhere and even other seller here on Amazon. Any rate I am absolutely satisfied with mine. I bought an .83” riser to co witness my AR15 BUIS and everything has just been flawless. I’m watching this thing And if the price drops again I’ll probably pick up 2-3 more as I’m always tinkering with my collection. For me and the one I got it was an extremely super deal and a great quality sight.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Took no time at all to zero!
review_text: Worked like a charm. @ 10 yards only took 1 shot to zero in and @ 25 yards took 2 shots. Used my thumbnail to adjust the screws for it, wish it would of come with some sort of tool to do it instead. Might recommend someone bring a stubby flat head screwdriver to make this job easier. The build quality appears to be top-notch as is the clarity. After 80 rounds of 9mm after zero'ing in @ 25 yards the sight never wandered. All in all I was very impressed and I would definitely recommend. Tip: If you have a rifle or carbine with iron sights you want to keep make sure you order a riser! For this red dot I ordered the below riser and it worked perfectly with my iron sights and kept the TRS-25 high enough so my ear protection and glasses didn't get in the way of my sight picture. UTG Med-pro Compact Riser Mount, 0.83" High, 3 Slots *update March 2019* Bought my third one they are so good.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: How to beat this for the $$$?
review_text: This is a great optic. I own many other higher priced red dots but this is perfect for where it's perfect. For a shotgun or pistol, good luck finding a better optic for the price. I didn't want to mount an Aimpoint PRO or Strikefire II on my shotgun or on my pistols. Cost wasn't the factor. The factor was size. This filled the niche in a fantastic way. While I prefer the Vortex Venom, this is a nice way to add a sight to your shotgun. For a pistol, I'd still go with the Venom.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Bought 2: one has 200 12ga slugs/buck/bird thru it, other has 1,000 5.56mm AR15 rounds through it. Color me seriously impressed.
review_text: Spent a weekend doing a 3 gun training course. Broke every common sense rule by installing these Bushnell TRS-25's on both my AR15 and MKA1919 12ga at the range, with only my backup iron sights if they failed in any way: you know that feeling when everything works right for once, and you feel like you actually got away with something that experience says no one gets away with? Yep, that's me. Crisp, clear lenses. Rock solid dial in that never changed all weekend. Dot was visible in bright sunlight without ever having to "find it", and on lower settings there was negligible light corruption - on par with much more expensive red dots. Was worried its small diameter would be too much to overcome but that was mostly a groundless problem. Drawbacks: on high settings, both of them have bad light contamination (red dot light source leaks and turns the whole lens area red tinged). You don't notice in it the bright conditions where you would need max power, but high end ones don't have that problem. 2nd is that it has small lenses which in a combat or home defense situation could leave you spending a precious second realigning your head to get the dot back in your view.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Very solid sight for the money - Needs a wider range of brightness settings
review_text: Excellent design, build quality and form factor for the price. The large 25 mm FOV makes it easy to quickly find the dot, even without a perfect cheek weld. The only major disadvantage is that even on the dimmest brightness setting, the dot is too bright for some situations - and is completely unusable with night vision gear. Bushnell doesn't publish any battery life estimates - so here are my current consumption measurements, along with the corresponding battery life estimates: Brightness Setting: Measured Current: Estimated Battery Life (w/225 mAH battery): 1 0.3 mA 750 hours 2 0.48 mA 470 hours 3 0.78 mA 290 hours 4 1.33 mA 170 hours 5 1.92 mA 117 hours 6 3.18 mA 71 hours 7 4.54 mA 50 hours 8 6.74 mA 33 hours 9 10.9 mA 21 hours 10 15.5 mA 14.5 hours 11 26.2 mA 8.6 hours As a point of reference, Trijicon's MRO sight draws just several microamps at the lowest brightness setting - roughly 100 times less than this sight. Then again, the MRO sells for roughly 8 times more than this sight.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I have 3 of these and use them on .6 inch risers on AR-15 platform rifles. Planning to purchase 3 more to replace some inexpensive (yes, less than these) optics I've been using on additional rifles. At the price I will probably replace the larger optics on my original Winchester 290 PROS 1) They are affordable and do a good job. 2) Locked up tight and haven't budged after 300+ rounds 3) They were easy to sight-in and have not had to redo. 4) Target acquisition is easy after getting use to the sight. I shoot with both eyes open and this was easy to adjust to 5) Outdoor shooting, I turn up the brightness, (not past 3rd or 4th setting). Indoor, I use 2nd setting. CONS 1) Not really a con if you know what you're purchasing. This is a compact red-dot sight, not one of the larger optics that use a lot of real estate on the rail. If you're looking for a sight that looks really cool and fancy on the rifle, this may not be for you. This red-dot is made for ease of attachment, good performance and still looks good on your weapon.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Exceptional red dot for the price
review_text: I own two of these, one on my ruger 9mm pc carbine and the other on my savage 64 22lr both hold zero very well, the brightness goes to 11 so its extra bright, battery life is outstanding if you remember to turn it off before putting it away, I paid $60 for each more than worth every penny, dot is a little larger than I would like at 3moa but everyone that uses it compliments the accuracy, I would definitely recommend it, now if you want something better id get the 2 moa sig sauer Romeo 5 at $120

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: The dot is very bright and crisp and I like the fact the brightness adjustment knob is firm and ...
review_text: I was looking for an inexpensive red dot scope to mount on my AK. Read lots of positive reviews about this scope so I decided to purchase one. The dot is very bright and crisp and I like the fact the brightness adjustment knob is firm and "clicks" with each adjustment this insures it will not move unless you move it, no accidental "on" which insures I wouldn't drain the battery. The Bushnell TRS-25 Red Dot performed very well during my first time at the range. I shot multiple 3-shot groups at a distance of ~30yards. Zeroing the scope, I found the windage and elevation adjustment to be firm and could detect positive click positions. I adjusted the scope slightly (both windage & elevation) to achieve zero, I was pleasantly pleased it didn't take much to get it zero'd in, approximately nine shots and I very achieving very tight centered groups :-). I also set clay pigeons out to 60yards and I was delighted that I could easy pick them off...Love this scope! Since I was shooting in the early morning facing east with the sun low on the eastern horizon I had the illumination of the red dot set on the "5" power, which was perfect for the light conditions. I am very pleased with the results during my initial outing but time will tell whether this scope can stand up to an AK. Bottom line, at this point I can recommend this scope especially at this price!

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I love this red dot sight! I did have to buy a rise for it, but other than that, this Trophy TRS-25 is locked on and I'm glad I bought it! You will need to sight it in, but after that, you'll be smoooooth sailing. The red dot's brightness can be adjusted 1 - 11 brightness dial (0 is off) -- the windage and elevation can also be adjusted with a small flat head screwdriver -- and this red dot works great! Good price, good quality, good time at the range! SIDEBAR: I do use mine at an *indoor range so I cannot attest to its outdoor capabilities. Shooting at a 300-yard (simulated) silhouette target at 25-yards and the red dot set at level 9, it works perfectly. Invest in this Bushnell TRS-25, you won't be sorry.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: just got back from the shooting range (ruger mini 14/xm193 ammo). got it zeroed in,was a breeze,just 3 clicks left,1 click down at 50 yards. Moved out to 100yards, one more click left....perfect...30 rounds,13 inside 4 moa. the rest just out side of 4 moa averaging around 5 moa. 100 yards on a 20-25 mph gusty day....i'll take it anytime. dot brightness i was at 4 on 50 yard had to bump it to 7 on 100 yard. did shoot 10 rounds 200 yards on 12 inch target hitting 3 o'clock on target about 5 inches of center, probably 1 more click left would of made it perfect, but windy day,i'll leave it for now. If your looking for a not to break the piggy bank red dot,go no further then the TRS 25 Bushnell.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: It works, it lasts, it's accurate.
review_text: This is a good sight! Brightness adjustment is a plus, considering how inexpensive it is. Once dialed in it's doing its job in spades at 25 to 50 yards. No magnification. Anything beyond 50 yards is a stretch, as the dot is quite large at even 75 yards. Shooting at distance at the range is a crapshoot. But for home defense, it's perfect. This is a great optic to have, I imagine most ARs have had this or similar CCO's on them at one time. Keep your CR-2032 batteries on hand just in case, very few scopes WON'T use them. Get em bulk and cheap. As a first time AR-builder/owner, I'm really happy with the Bushnell. It's not the know all end all but it certainly is a great addition to a short to medium range AR. If you're tall like me - get a one inch riser! This RDS was useless without one (for my liking)! Now it sits perfectly.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Tough, Cheap, Small, Red dot sight
review_text: I was aware of the reviews, warning of the differences between earlier(gold lettering) and current(white lettering). I'm happy to say that Bushnell has corrected the new versions flaws. It has a crisp red dot, a firm and positive brightness knob, the emitter is at the 4:30 position and can be seen clearly. It doesn't interfere with Co-witness and doesn't disappear at 10 o'clock. It is rugged enough to make a airline trip across country and held it's zero. I'm gonna buy more and recommend it to my friends.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: First, this little guy sets on top of my .22 LR auto. It’s a small unit and it’s weight mirrors it’s smallness. I decided I’d try the bushnell on my .22 and see if it could fill the place of a more expensive item. I’ve had the optic now for a little over two years and have changed the battery 3 times over that period. It’s been through a lot of use and the one thing I keep coming back to is that I can almost drive nails with it. The mount is solid but the fact that it keeps coming in and shooting straight is a major plus. I know quality optics. I have 2 other Aimpoints and one Trijicon as well as a slew of other glass. So, would I mount this on my everyday use AR? To be truthful, I would, except I worry about it’s toughness and I worry about battery consumption, but hey what can you expect for 60.00? No I leave my everyday use for the big boys, and we all know who they are. Now, would I buy a couple of these for my .20 gauge and my .22lr? Hunting use? Absolutely, that realm of hobby is a great place for this optic and it fits well in that realm. Though I’ve not thrower it out of the back of my truck or dragged it across America, it is reasonable tough and genuinely water proof. I do recollect it falling mounted down a set of basement stairs and surviving and I remember setting through a weekend of torrential rain with it frog hunting. Scope and gun soaked. It survived with ease. If I broke this dot I would replace it with 2 more. Solid optic at a great price. Hope this helps! Cheers!

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Cowitnesses perfectly on a CS Scorpion EVO3 S1
review_text: Im not really a fan of it cowitnessing on the scorpion. The irons can easily be removed. I leave the irons on anyways just in case I forget to turn off the red dot and I dont have a spare battery. I do like I can go from 0 to 10 in one click. Some other red dots will only allow you to turn it to full after going through all of the lower settings. When outside, in the sun, its nice to just turn it to full power, then off instead of clicking through all levels in between.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Fear not. Dot does not dissapear
review_text: So I've read some reviews about this red dot for a while before deciding to purchase it. There have been some complaints about the dot disappearing if moved into a certain spot in the optic, or that the dot isn't that bright. I can say with confidence that those issues are no longer a thing for these red dots (at least for mine) and are a pretty decent value for the money. Great for the boogaloo that will soon be upon us. Prepare brothers! Update: went out to the range and was able to zero it in a few minutes. Haven't noticed any shift after 700 rounds and is accurate if you do your part. Good option for 22s and pistol caliber carbines IMO.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Perfect fit on my Ruger PCC9
review_text: It's a red dot for 25 - 50 (maybe 100 at most) yards. Not for for a .338 Lapua at 1500 yds., OK? I mounted this sturdy, well built sight on my 2018 Ruger PCC9 - original stock (now in a Midwest Industries chassis). The iron sights are tight to the bore axis so no riser needed for this red dot. It zero's perfectly. It's as if the Ruger designers had this Bushnell in mind. Very little paralax! Bright dot outdoors in the intense New Mexico sun. So, go ahead and drop more on a Sig or Holosun. They're great. But this is a $500 carbine for fun...and home defense not a CMMG Banshee or Sig MPX. This little red dot does the trick for less than $100. I couldn't be more pleased.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: I use this red dot on my Mossberg 500 with rifled slugs. It stays on point, zeroed even with a 12 gauge, which is impressive to me. Those 3 inch cartridges are some hot rounds that pack a punch. I've only bought cheaper red dots in the past, and not a single one of them would stay zeroed when I put them on my 12 gauge. The Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 truly fits the old saying - you get what you pay for. There's a reason some red dots are 20 bucks and some are closer to $100 or higher. Its because they can be mounted on a high recoil rifle and stay zeroed. I love this red dot.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: This red dot seems to be very well made, and it was super easy to install. I went to the range this past weekend, and it was super easy to get zeroed in, and it stayed accurate after shooting a box of 20 rounds. I used a boresighter as well, so I did not put any more money down range than I needed to. I used about 5 rounds after using the boresighter to get it zeroed, and the rest was just for fun. I do wish it had an auto off feature though. Just make sure you turn it off after use, to not allow the battery to drain. I also recommend getting a riser mount for your sight. It raises the sight enough to make it comfortable to see through. It was hard to use without this riser. You can see the riser in the picture. Have a great day!

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Great red dot for the price
review_text: If you were like me, wanting or needing a new red dot but there just wasn't money for the 100 dollar and up red dots everyone else has, Well, this red dot is for you. It works great! it is really bright, in the sun. I took it out the day I got it and turned it on to make sure I could see it. You will need a riser for this for your AR if you didn't know. There is one on here for 8 dollars that worked great for me. I got the UTG Med-Pro compact riser mount. I took it to the range, zeroed it in at 150 yards, and proceeded to put a 1,000 rounds through it and just had fun just to make sure it holds the zero etc, and it held up strong. The only complaint I would have, is the dials are super tight when turning. Not a bad thing, I at least know they are not going anywhere in transport but just an FYI. But for the cost, it is a great red dot.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Sig 522 - EXCELLENT Primary Sight for Survival Weapon
review_text: Exactly what I've been looking for! I am EXTREMELY picky about my red dot sights because I want something that is durable, effective, small, and lightweight - this meets all of my criteria and then some. I've owned this sight for all of about a month, but it has performed extremely well thus far. BATTERY LIFE The battery life exceeds that of an EO Tech which as all of you know is 5x the price of the Bushnell unit. The battery life for the Bushnell TRS-25 is 3,000 hours, whereas the EO Tech is only 1,000 hours. That means you can leave your TRS-25 in the ON position for 125 days straight before the battery runs out, hence if you carry 2 spare batteries, you can run this red dot for well over a year straight! The caveat here is that this assumes you leave it on one of the lower settings, but even still that's super amazing. DURABILITY If you'd like to see how durable this unit is , please search YouTube for "TRS-25 torture test".There is a guy that mounts this sight to his SKS, shoots several hundred rounds in a row, drops the gun/sight from 5 feet and then proceeds to shoot with it from 100 yards!!!! When dropped the sight put a dent in the wood! and it still held zero! How's that for durability?! WATERPROOF Per Bushnell, this sight is waterproof and can be submerged, however, all caps must be tightened prior to doing so. And I belive that I read it's okay to submerge in water up to 5' deep. FINAL THOUGHTS Great red dot, will buy another for the price. Sounds like some people had issues with theirs, and that made me a little apprehensive at first, but with Amazons return policy and Bushnell's 1 year warranty, I figured I'd give it a shot. If you don't have the funds for an EO Tech or AIM Point, then this is the sight for you. I installed this on my Sig 522, if anything goes wrong I will update this review.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: For the cost you get a good red dot that stays on zero, is pretty durable, and has excellent battery life. I've used it on a snappy 7.5" AR15 Pistol for a couple of years, and now it's on Ruger PC9 Carbine that has more than 700 rounds through it. The red dot has done great. The only down side is the "halo" you get when you turn up the brightness past 7, 8, 9, and to 10. Not really a big deal for me because I usually use levels 5-6. I would give it 3 stars for this but for general plinking and normal use this is solid option and the cost alone takes it to 5 stars.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: It took two tries to get a good one, but I did!
review_text: The first one of these Bushnell TRS-25 red-dot sights I got from Amazon was defective. I couldn't get the red dot to move no matter how much I turned the adjustment screws. I notified Amazon yesterday afternoon, and got instructions on how to return it for a refund or a new sight. I wanted a new sight. It came in the mail TODAY! In about 18 hours since I filed my complaint I had a new sight in hand. I live in rural Ohio, how did they do that? The new sight is mounted on my rifle and the sight co-witnesses with the iron sights so I assume it is dialed in pretty close. It seems to me that the adjustment screws are backward for the direction they move the dot. But, after trying both directions after realizing that correction made it worse, I got it set up. The dot is bright and is a solid dot even at bright settings. Mounting is easy. My rifle give a bottom 1/3 co-witness with my iron sights. I am pleased!

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Very Good Red Dot Site for Hi-Point 995
review_text: After reading good reviews in other forums I decided to purchase this red dot for my Hi-Point 995TS This was the first red dot that I owned. I couldn't believe how much faster it is to find the target using the red dot scope over the iron sights. I zeroed it in at 10, 25 and 50 yards. It worked great. At 50 yard and maximum intensity the shot group is about 3 to 6 inches. The sight has 11 dot brightness settings. The 1st setting is the lowest intensity and on a white or green background in the middle of a sunny day I could see the red dot but it was very faint. On the 11th setting or highest intensity I could see perfectly in broad day light. Update: I have had the TRS mounted to my gun now for a few months. I took it out and shot about 500 rounds through my gun and it was spot on. I shoot with a bunch a friends at cans and paper. We make bets who can hit target the most and other simple games shooting at the target. My friends hate it when I get my gun out because it is almost like cheating with the red dot.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Very good Budget Red dot optic!
review_text: This product is very well done for a budget red dot sight I have been putting threw its paces with shooting about 500 rounds it has been dropped and tested for sight alignment with no changes like most reviewers I will mention The glue looking part in the sight which is overlapping where the red dot is glowing threw the sight I tried multiple times to show it threw to get a picture but keep coming out blurry however I did manage to get some pictures of the red dot optic, Now keep in mind my experience will differ due to the face I am running a S$W M@P 15-22 chambered just incase some don't know in 22 Long Rifle ammunition with virtually no recoil but for the application I am using it for works beautifully and Highly recommend to buy it if you are looking for a reliable red dot. Plus the red dot was very bright much brighter than some others reviewed to be less than now the pictures wont truly show how bright it was but I am being honest when I say it is more than bright enough even at the brightest parts of the day.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Amazing Bang-for-Buck (no pun intended) Entry Level Red Dot!
review_text: I really can't say enough good things about this red dot. It's super affordable, easy to attach, easy to adjust, and very clear to see. The brightness setting dial is a bit stiff, but I'd rather it be a little too stiff than loose. There is a bit of ghosting on the glass when you turn the dot up brighter, but honestly the brightest settings on this thing are almost too bright, so you'll likely not have an issue with this. Pros: - The price - huge bang-for-buck value (no pun intended) - Very sturdy - this thing is attached to a Beretta CX4 Storm 9mm Carbine, and isn't having an issue with it. - Plenty bright (and brighter than you'll need) - Easy to attach - Easy to adjust Cons: - Again, there is some ghosting on the glass when you have the dot turned up in brightness, but only at the higher levels, which has so far been unnecessary for me. - The brightness dial is a bit stiffer than I'd like, but again, I'd rather it be that way rather than too loose. Overall, the con's were a stretch and not enough for me to deduct stars. This thing is an amazing starter red dot. 5 stars all day long. P.S. If anyone else is looking for a red dot for their CX4 Storm, this is the way to go. It has such a low profile, it aligns perfectly with the CX4's built in "iron" sights.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Looks good and works great on my Keltec Sub 2k.
review_text: I installed this scope on a KelTec Sub 2000 Gen2 rifle. It is added to a MCARBO scope mount and was able to be co-witnessed with the factory sights. The red dot is sharp and on center. The nature of the Sub2000 is that it can be folded and packed away. The mount pivots away to the side so that the rifle can fold. So you would think that continued folding actions would cause it to go out of zero...but its just as good as day 1. I'm happy with my purchase.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: Picked this up after trying dozens of cheap chinese red dot sights and having none of them hold a zero on any of my guns. Decided that I probably have to spend at least $50 to get a sight that won't die after 1 range day. I was right. This is the best one I have gotten yet and I'll likely end up buying another for another one of my guns. Right now I have it mounted at 45 degrees next to my rifle scope on my AR because it's size is super manageable. Easy to operate, no fiddling around by turning screws forever until the dot moves because it moves on every click of the knobs like it should (first one I've had that does). Zero'd the sight in no shots at all, just lined it up with where my scope was zero'd and fired one round to see where it went and sure enough, it went exactly where I aimed. Honestly I can't say enough about this sight. It's sturdy, well built and I would most certainly recommend it to anyone looking for a budget red dot sight because I think this one is at the floor level of what you can pay to get something that just works. Now I just need to convince my dad to stop buying the one's that SAY Bushnell that are Chinese rip offs and just pick up the real deal. Side note, this sight is made in China but it doesn't look like it, and they had to cut cost somewhere along the line so it is more affordable.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: It's Bushnell and appears to be the expected Bushnell quality. Nothin' fancy, but it works well. Low-profile and compact (I was surprised HOW compact!). Mounts perfectly on my Ruger carbine, allowing it to co-witness with the iron sights, which are in the bottom quarter of the field of view. Solid mount. The only demerit I give it is for the cheap lens cover, which is not very secure.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Great little Red dot for the money
review_text: Great little Red dot for the money! Co-witnesses great with a UTG medium riser and magpul sights. Or any flip up sights for that matter, as long as you are using on an AR type platform. The only small cons that I would give this sight is the fact that the knob is a little tight to move and has I think 10 or 12 settings thus making you have to crank it a few times to get into the middle range where you will probably be using the red dot. The other con is that I am not a fan of the bikini cover if you are using this for home defense and have to get at it in a hurry. I ordered the butler creek lens covers and they fit pretty well. The front will stay on for the most part, but the back (closest to your eye) you will probably need some epoxy. I used the 30mm butler creeks. Be careful when ordering the butler creek covers though as I have experienced that their SPRING hinged covers in 30mm do nor fit by quite a bit, but the rubber ones that you manually flip up until they stop do fit. Hope this helps.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_text: Bushnell fixed the things I didn't like about my TRS-25 AR Optics w/ white logo & LED at 6 o'clock that I've had for a few months. Now, the lowest setting is dimmer & more distinct in low light conditions. The highest setting is so bright, I doubt I'll ever have a reason to go that high. I really liked my TRS-25 AR Optic (on a UTG Super Slim .83" riser), until I got this Trophy. Both are parallax free, tough built, 3 MOA dot, good battery life, good windage & elevation adjustment. I also liked my Primary Arms MD-FBGII, because of the 2 MOA dot, but it's not parallax free. This new Trophy is my favorite of the three. Some critics will appreciate the fact that the dot remains visible throughout the field of view. The dot is perfectly round (when viewed through my phone camera). I see a different shape with the naked eye but I know it's not a problem with the optic. When I rotate the optic, the starburst does not spin with it. There were no external defects. The box was sealed with two transparent stickers so I could tell it was new. This one has a gray logo, but it seems to be constructed like the ones with the gold-greenish logo. The only thing I don't like is, it looks like they got a little sloppy with the glue on the LED. I'm not bothered by the LED partially obstructing the view but the glob of glue on mine is so big, the LED looks round. Perhaps it'll hold better against shock. Any other complaint would be unrealistic at this price. I'm so thrilled, I'm writing my review the same day I got this one. I want to grab another one in case I find somewhere to mount it.

product_title: Bushnell Trophy TRS-25 Red Dot Sight Riflescope, 1x20mm, Black
review_header: Warning - The primary Amazon photo is incorrect! Shows the discontinued model
review_text: When you first browse this TRS-25 on Amazon, the main display page shows a photo of the sight with the Bushnell Logo in a small font printed in Yellow/Gold. That is an old image. Do not buy this sight thinking or hoping you will receive once with the Yellow logo version like shown in the original Amazon photo. You will get the newer model with a White/Silver logo... even the one Sold and shipped by Amazon! The primary reason for mentioning this is … if you’ve spent any time reading various internet forums and reviews, or taken the time to peruse all the reviews here in Amazon, it's common to find warnings about TRS-25’s with a white versus the yellow Bushnell logo. Also, do not buy this sight if you are attempting (as some suggest) to play the “Yellow Logo lottery” hoping you will receive one with a yellow logo and not a white one. That lottery trick / suggestion is also quite old. It may have worked back in early 2015 when Bushnell first did the redesign but all the old stock has long since been exhausted. The logo color warnings are not relevant, i.e., ones that state the original yellow/gold Bushnell logo is found on models that are made in Japan and better quality when compared to the newer models with the Bushnell logo in white that are now coming out of China. Some of the negative review complaint examples: Red dot is about half as bright. Red dot is not centered in display Red dot is distorted End lens is Green no long Red/orange So... are the current Chinese models inferior to the Japanese model? Not really. Bushnells production quality guideline standards are strictly enforced regardless of the country of origin. Have there been problems or complaints about receiving units with manufacturing defects? Yes! BUT... there are three good reasons: 1) If you take the time to read ALL the negative reviews you will discover a lot of them are pre-2015 when the units were shipping from Japan.
